questions.stem: What is the recommended length for an executive summary?

options.label: 1-2 pages or 10% of total length maximum
As long as necessary to cover all points

questions.rationale: Executive summaries should be 1-2 pages for most reports, or maximum 10% of the total document length.

questions.stem: Arrange these report sections in the correct order:
questions.rationale: This is the standard order for government report sections, following established conventions.

questions.stem: Complete this recommendation format: '__________ 1: That the Department __________ a new training program by March 2025, as outlined in Section 4.2, to address the __________.'
questions.rationale: Recommendations should be numbered, specific, actionable, and reference supporting sections.

questions.stem: Match the organizational pattern with its best use:
questions.rationale: Different organizational patterns serve different purposes in report structure.

questions.stem: What should be included in the introduction section?

options.label: Only the purpose of the report
Background, purpose, scope, methodology, and limitations

questions.rationale: The introduction should provide context, purpose, scope, methodology, and any limitations of the report.

questions.stem: Which heading style shows the best parallel structure?

options.label: Analyzing Budget, Cost Savings, What We Recommend
Analyzing Current Budget, Identifying Cost Savings, Recommending Changes
Budget Analysis, How to Save Money, Our Recommendations
The Budget, Saving Money, What to Do Next

questions.rationale: Parallel structure uses consistent grammatical forms across headings (all -ing verbs in this case).

questions.stem: Complete this numbered heading system: 1. Introduction, 2. Current Situation, __________. Background, __________. Key Issues, 3. Recommendations
questions.rationale: The decimal numbering system uses 2.1, 2.2 for subsections under section 2.

questions.stem: Click on the heading that breaks parallel structure:
questions.text:
3.1 Analyzing Current Performance
3.2 Identifying Improvement Areas
3.3 What We Should Do Next
3.4 Implementing New Procedures

errors.reason: Should maintain parallel -ing structure like other headings

questions.rationale: All headings in a series should follow the same grammatical pattern.

questions.stem: Match the heading level with its typical format:
questions.rationale: Typography-based heading systems use different font treatments to show hierarchy.

questions.stem: How many heading levels should you typically use in a report?
questions.rationale: Reports should typically use no more than 4 heading levels to avoid confusion and maintain clarity.

questions.stem: What page numbering system should be used for front matter?
questions.rationale: Front matter typically uses Roman numerals (i, ii, iii) while main text uses Arabic numerals.

questions.stem: Complete the title page information: Report title, Subtitle (if needed), __________, Date of publication, Department name, __________
questions.rationale: Title pages should include author/organization and report number or file reference for identification.

questions.stem: Arrange the front matter components in correct order:
questions.rationale: This is the standard order for front matter components in government reports.

questions.stem: When should you include a List of Tables and Figures?

options.label: When there are 5 or more tables/figures

questions.rationale: Include a List of Tables and Figures when you have 5 or more tables/figures to help readers navigate.

questions.stem: What is the key requirement for an executive summary?

options.label: It must be a standalone document that makes sense without the full report
It should include all the data from the report
It should focus only on recommendations

questions.rationale: The executive summary must be self-contained and provide all key information for decision-makers.

questions.stem: When should you use tables instead of charts?

options.label: When readers need exact values and detailed comparisons
When showing proportions of a whole

questions.rationale: Tables are best for exact values, detailed comparisons, and reference data; charts are better for trends and patterns.

questions.stem: Complete the table citation: '__________ 1: Budget Allocations by Department ($ millions)' followed by the table, then '__________ : Public Accounts of Canada, 2024'
questions.rationale: Tables should be numbered sequentially, have descriptive titles above, and cite sources below.

questions.stem: Match the chart type with its best use:
questions.rationale: Different chart types are designed for different kinds of data relationships.

questions.stem: Click on the missing element in this table reference:
questions.text: Budget allocations increased significantly across departments, as detailed in the attached spreadsheet.

errors.reason: Should specifically reference the table number

questions.rationale: Tables and figures should be specifically referenced by number in the text.

questions.stem: What accessibility consideration is important for charts?

options.label: Use as many colors as possible
Don't rely solely on color to convey information
Make text as small as possible

questions.rationale: Charts should not rely solely on color because of color blindness; use patterns, shapes, or labels as well.

questions.stem: What is the most common type of minutes for government committees?
questions.rationale: Summary minutes that capture key points of discussion and outcomes are most common for government meetings.

questions.stem: Complete this motion record: 'M. Brown moved that the committee __________ approval of the Digital Services Strategy. Seconded by L. Wong. __________.'
questions.rationale: Motion records should include the mover, the motion text, seconder, and outcome (Carried/Defeated).

questions.stem: Click on the incorrect writing style in these minutes:
questions.text: We decided to approve the budget. The committee felt that our previous concerns had been addressed. I think this was a good decision.

errors.reason: Minutes should use third person, not first person
Minutes should be objective, not personal opinion

questions.rationale: Minutes should use third person, past tense, and objective language.

questions.stem: Match the minutes section with its content:
questions.rationale: Different sections of minutes serve specific documentation purposes.

questions.stem: When should draft minutes be circulated?
questions.rationale: Draft minutes should be circulated within 48 hours while the meeting is still fresh in participants' minds.
